SENT.plain: The minimum prevalence of lethal Osteogenesis imperfecta type II, thanatophoric dysplasia and achondroplasia were derived following detailed case note review of all perinatal lethal skeletal dysplasias (SD) in Northern Ireland over a 12 year period
Multiple sources of ascertainment, including genetic notes, radiological reports and post mortem findings, were used
Thanatophoric dysplasia was the commonest diagnosis made (22), followed by osteogenesis imperfecta type II (four children) and achondroplasia (two children)
Eleven other diagnoses each occurred once in the 12 year period

The minimum prevalence range, per live births, of each of the common skeletal dysplasias in Northern Ireland has been calculated; thanatophoric dysplasia 0.80/10,000, osteogenesis imperfecta type II 0.15/10,000 and achondroplasia 0.07/10,000
The prevalence range for thanatophoric dysplasia is much higher than reported in previous studies
We discuss reasons for the prevalence figures obtained
